|Item_parent_short=Main complications of pregnancy.
|Rank=B
|Title=Savoir prescrire et interpréter les examens complémentaires en cas d'HTA gravidique.
|Description=Know how to interpret a urinary albumin/creatinine ratio to rule out pre-eclampsia, a rise in creatinine in a pregnant woman, know how to request obstetriocal exemns to assess foetal development.
|Rubric=Additional examinations
|Contributors=Paul Berveiller,Philippe Deruelle
|Order=10}}

'''On the maternal level'''

The discovery of gestational hypertension = look for pre-eclampsia++.

- The only essential test is to look for ''[[Proteinuria SD-212|proteinuria]]'' on a sample (>1 cross at BU) or on a 24-hour urine collection (>300 mg/24 h).

- A P/C ratio greater than 30 indicates positive proteinuria and should be followed by quantification by analysis of 24-hour proteinuria. If the P/C ratio is less than 30, there is no significant proteinuria.

'''On the foetal level'''

- Obstetrical ultrasound + Doppler'' :

- fetal biometrics with estimation of fetal weight

- assesses growth with comparison to previous ultrasound scans where appropriate

- in the case of IUGR: umbilical artery Doppler analysis (placental resistances) and biometric curves.

Fetuses with IUGR and no umbilical Doppler are at high risk of "in utero" foetal death and acidosis.

RCF: Of limited interest in moderate and isolated hypertension, it is essential for monitoring severe forms and/or IUGR with pathological umbilical Doppler.

question.title: Interpretation of a urinary albumin/creatinine ratio in a pregnant woman
question.description: A pregnant woman has a urinary albumin/creatinine ratio of 20. What is the next step?

option_a.title: Request a 24-hour urine collection to quantify proteinuria
option_a.description: This option is correct because a ratio of 30 or greater indicates positive proteinuria and requires further quantification.

option_b.title: Perform an obstetrical ultrasound with Doppler to assess fetal growth
option_b.description: This option is incorrect because it is not directly related to interpreting the urinary albumin/creatinine ratio. However, it is a useful test for assessing fetal growth and development.

option_c.title: Order a 24-hour urine collection to quantify proteinuria
option_c.description: This option is incorrect because it is the same as option A, and the ratio of 20 is not indicative of significant proteinuria.

option_d.title: Refer the patient to a specialist for further evaluation
option_d.description: This option is incorrect because the patient's condition does not require immediate specialist referral based on the provided information.

correct_option.title: Option A
correct_option.description: This option is correct because a ratio of 20 is less than 30, and further quantification is not necessary.
